Luxuriant Vale, thy country's early boast,</br>What time great GLENDOUR gave thy scenes to Fame;</br>Taught the proud numbers of the English Host,</br>How vain their vaunted force, when Freedom's flame</br>Fir'd him to brave the Myriads he abhorr'd,</br>Wing'd his unerring shaft, and edg'd his victor sword.

Here first those orbs unclosing drank the light,</br>Cambria's bright stars, the meteors of her Foes;</br>What dread and dubious omens mark'd the night,</br>That lour'd ere yet his natal morn arose!</br>The Steeds paternal, on their cavern'd floor,</br>Foaming, and horror-struck, "fret fetlock-deep in gore."

PLAGUE, in her livid hand, o'er all the Isle,</br>Shook her dark flag, impure with fetid stains;</br>While "DEATH, on his pale Horse," with baleful smile,</br>Smote with its blasting hoof the frighted plains.</br>Soon thro' the grass-grown streets, in silence led,</br>Slow moves the midnight Cart, heapt with the naked Dead.

Yet in the festal dawn of Richard's reign,</br>Thy gallant GLENDOUR'S sunny prime arose;</br>Virtuous, tho' gay, in that Circean fane,</br>Bright Science twin'd her circlet round his brows;</br>Nor cou'd the youthful, rash, luxurious King</br>Dissolve the Hero's worth on his Icarian wing.

Sudden it drops on its meridian flight!—</br>Ah!  hapless Richard!  never didst thou aim</br>To crush primeval Britons with thy might,</br>And their brave Glendour's tears embalm thy name.</br>Back from thy victor-Rival's vaunting Throng,</br>Sorrowing, and stern, he sinks LLANGOLLEN'S shades among.

Soon, in imperious Henry's dazzled eyes,</br>The guardian bounds of just Dominion melt;</br>His scarce-hop'd crown imperfect bliss supplies,</br>Till Cambria's vassalage be deeply felt.</br>Now up her craggy steeps, in long array,</br>Swarm his exulting Bands, impatient for the fray.

Lo!  thro' the gloomy night, with angry blaze,</br>Trails the fierce Comet, and alarms the Stars;</br>Each waning Orb withdraws its glancing rays,</br>Save the red Planet, that delights in wars.</br>Then, with broad eyes upturn'd, and starting hair,</br>Gaze the astonish'd Crowd upon its vengeful glare.

Gleams the wan Morn, and thro' LLANGOLLEN'S Vale</br>Sees the proud Armies streaming o'er her meads.</br>Her frighted Echos warning sounds assail,</br>Loud, in the rattling cars, the neighing steeds;</br>The doubling drums, the trumpet's piercing breath,</br>And all the ensigns dread of havoc, wounds, and death.

High on a hill as shrinking CAMBRIA stood,</br>And watch'd the onset of th' unequal fray,</br>She saw her Deva, stain'd with warrior-blood,</br>Lave the pale rocks, and wind its fateful way</br>Thro' meads, and glens, and wild woods, echoing far</br>The din of clashing arms, and furious shout of war.

From rock to rock, with loud acclaim, she sprung,</br>While from her CHIEF the routed Legions fled;</br>Saw Deva roll their slaughter'd heaps among,</br>The check'd waves eddying round the ghastly dead;</br>Saw, in that hour, her own LLANGOLLEN claim</br>Thermopylae's bright wreath, and aye-enduring fame.

Thus, consecrate to GLORY. — Then arose</br>A milder lustre in its blooming maze;</br>Thro' the green glens, where lucid Deva flows,</br>Rapt Cambria listens with enthusiast gaze,</br>While more enchanting sounds her ear assail,</br>Than thrill'd on Sorga's bank, the Love-devoted Vale.

'Mid the gay towers on steep Din's Branna's cone,</br>Her HOEL'S breast the fair MIFANWY fires.—</br>O!  Harp of Cambria, never hast thou known</br>Notes more mellifluent floating o'er the wires,</br>Than when thy Bard this brighter Laura sung,</br>And with his ill-starr'd love LLANGOLLEN'S echoes rung.

Tho' Genius, Love, and Truth inspire the strains,</br>Thro' Hoel's veins tho' blood illustrious flows,</br>Hard as th' Eglwyseg rocks her heart remains,</br>Her smile a sun-beam playing on their snows;</br>And nought avails the Poet's warbled claim,</br>But, by his well-sung woes, to purchase deathless fame.

Thus consecrate to LOVE, in ages flown,—</br>Long ages fled Din's-Branna's ruins show,</br>Bleak as they stand upon their steepy cone,</br>The crown and contrast of the VALE below,</br>That, screen'd by mural rocks, with pride displays</br>Beauty's romantic pomp in every sylvan maze.

Now with a vestal lustre glows the VALE,</br>Thine, sacred FRIENDSHIP, permanent as pure;</br>In vain the stern Authorities assail,</br>In vain Persuasion spreads her silken lure,</br>High-born, and high-endow'd, the peerless Twain,</br>Pant for coy Nature's charms 'mid silent dale, and plain.

Thro' ELEANORA, and her ZARA'S mind,</br>Early tho'genius, taste, and fancy flow'd,</br>Tho' all the graceful Arts their powers combin'd,</br>And her last polish brilliant Life bestow'd,</br>The lavish Promiser, in Youth's soft morn,</br>Pride, Pomp, and Love, her friends, the sweet Enthusiasts scorn.

Then rose the Fairy Palace of the Vale,</br>Then bloom'd around it the Arcadian bowers;</br>Screen'd from the storms of Winter, cold and pale,</br>Screen'd from the fervours of the sultry hours,</br>Circling the lawny crescent, soon they rose,</br>To letter'd ease devote, and Friendship's blest repose.

Smiling they rose beneath the plastic hand</br>Of Energy, and Taste; — nor only they,</br>Obedient Science hears the mild command,</br>Brings every gift that speeds the tardy day,</br>Whate'er the pencil sheds in vivid hues,</br>Th' historic tome reveals, or sings the raptured Muse.

How sweet to enter, at the twilight grey,</br>The dear, minute Lyceum of the Dome,</br>When, thro' the colour'd crystal, glares the ray,</br>Sanguine and solemn 'mid the gathering gloom,</br>While glow-worm lamps diffuse a pale, green light,</br>Such as in mossy lanes illume the starless night.

Then the coy Scene, by deep'ning veils o'erdrawn,</br>In shadowy elegance seems lovelier still;</br>Tall shrubs, that skirt the semi-lunar lawn,</br>Dark woods, that curtain the opposing hill;</br>While o'er their brows the bare cliff faintly gleams,</br>And, from its paly edge, the evening-diamond streams.

What strains Aeolian thrill the dusk expanse,</br>As rising gales with gentle murmurs play,</br>Wake the loud chords, or every sense intrance,</br>While in subsiding winds they sink away!</br>Like distant choirs, "when pealing organs blow,"</br>And melting voices blend, majestically slow.

"But ah!  what hand can touch the strings so fine,</br>Who up the lofty diapason roll</br>Such sweet, such sad, such solemn airs divine,</br>Then let them down again into the soul!"</br>The prouder sex as soon, with virtue calm,</br>Might win from this bright Pair pure Friendship's spotless palm.

What boasts Tradition, what th' historic Theme,</br>Stands it in all their chronicles confest</br>Where the soul's glory shines with clearer beam,</br>Than in our sea-zon'd bulwark of the West,</br>When, in this Cambrian Valley, Virtue shows</br>Where, in her own soft sex, its steadiest lustre glows?

Say, ivied VALLE CRUCIS, time-decay'd,</br>Dim on the brink of Deva's wandering floods,</br>Your riv'd arch glimmering thro' the tangled glade,</br>Your grey hills towering o'er your night of woods,</br>Deep in the Vale's recesses as you stand,</br>And, desolately great, the rising sigh command,

Say, lonely, ruin'd Pile, when former years</br>Saw your pale Train at midnight altars bow;</br>Saw SUPERSTITION frown upon the tears</br>That mourn'd the rash irrevocable vow,</br>Wore one young lip gay ELEANORA'S smile?</br>Did ZARA'S look serene one tedious hour beguile?

For your sad Sons, nor Science wak'd her powers;</br>Nor e'er did Art her lively spells display;</br>But the grim IDOL vainly lash'd the hours</br>That dragg'd the mute, and melancholy day;</br>Dropt her dark cowl on each devoted head,</br>That o'er the breathing Corse a pall eternal spread.

This gentle Pair no glooms of thought infest,</br>Nor Bigotry, nor Envy's sullen gleam</br>Shed withering influence on the effort blest,</br>Which most should win the other's dear esteem,</br>By added knowledge, by endowment high,</br>By Charity's warm boon, and Pity's soothing sigh.

Then how should Summer-day or Winter-night,</br>Seem long to them who thus can wing their hours!</br>O!  ne'er may Pain, or Sorrow's cruel blight,</br>Breathe the dark mildew thro' these lovely bowers,</br>But lengthen'd Life subside in soft decay,</br>Illum'd by rising Hope, and Faith's pervading ray.

May one kind ice-bolt, from the mortal stores,</br>Arrest each vital current as it flows,</br>That no sad course of desolated hours</br>Here vainly nurse the unsubsiding woes!</br>While all who honour Virtue, gently mourn</br>LLANGOLLEN'S VANISHED PAIR, and wreath their sacred urn.</br>
